subject: JUnit for folks who need good testing (was RE: [junit] TestCase Dependency Hierarchy)
msgSnippet: ... Ilja, ... Ilja, I was attempting to use sarcasm to make a point, and the wink was intended to convey that. I know e-mail is so tone flat, so maybe I
messageBody:
>> If your project has a big problem with core classes failing on a
>> regular basis, then maybe you have a process/people problem, as
> opposed to a technical problem.
>
> So junit is for folks who don't really need good testing? ;-)

Ilja,

> Adam, I don't fully understand your intent here, but your sentence does
> feel overly rude to me. The smiley really doesn't change much.

Ilja, I was attempting to use sarcasm to make a point, and the wink was
intended to convey that. I know e-mail is so tone flat, so maybe I shouldn't
have taken the risk, but I was not meaning to be rude. I apologize if that
is how it came off.

Also -- if you interpreted this as "junit isn't good", please don't. I was
replying to J.B saying if I had lots of core failures then I had other
problems, and I was saying --- don't folks w/ problems need good testing? I
hope the words in the sentence I wrote didn't come off as "junit is not
good".

That all said, please give me a break. I've praised jUnit, I've tolerated
jibes (so as not to start a flame war) and on the whole I've tried very hard
to be very level -- not try to score too many cheap points -- and keep a
healthy sense of humour, despite a lot of contentious comments.

I also think that the whole xJunit
community has done very much for the better regarding unit testing - it
doesn't deserve such comments.

But perhaps I am overreacting because I strongly feel as part of the
community you attacked with above sentence. I also don't understand at
all how it connects to J.B.'s suggestion (which I think probably isn't
totally misguided). Would you like to elaborate?

I didn't attack it at all. I think jUnit is awesome for helping me in the
early phase of rapid application development, and (once things grow) in the
retaining of contract knowledge. I use it most when I am refactoring a lot,
and when my code is breaking a lot. I was trying to make the point that that
is exactly when folks need junit the most...

Again, please forgive me if my choice of words failed to convey the correct
point.

regards,

Adam
